intro: Charlwoodia angustifolia, commonly known as narrowleaf charlwoodia, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils and is often found in wetlands and along stream banks. It produces showy, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its narrow, lance-shaped leaves and distinctive floral structure make it a notable species in its native habitat.
